body: Hot chocolate made with real chocolate is to cocoa what brioche is to bread, far more buttery and rich. author: Edward M. Gomez is a research fellow in the National Arts Journalism Program at Columbia University.
body: IT is no secret that Brooklyn's art scene has grown more active and visible since the mid-1980's, when artists, driven out of Manhattan by rising rents, began to move there. Today, artists from around the world have settled in districts like Red Hook, Dumbo (Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass), Greenpoint and especially Williamsburg. And
title: ART/ARCHITECTURE; Taking the Spirit of Brooklyn on a Florida Vacation

body: The weed-strewn parking lots and abandoned houses became a common sight here soon after I.B.M. left, turning this Hudson River city into just another example of the trail of upheaval left by corporate downsizing in the early 1990's. Over decades, I.B.M. had practically turned this part of eastern Ulster County into a company town. So when it closed
title: Technology Bubble Bursts Twice for a City That Pins Its Hopes on the New Economy

body: IF I were a young artist struggling to live, work and be noticed, I'd try Miami. At least this year. That was my thought one day last spring as I was poking around the studio that Naomi Fisher shares with Frank Benson in the working class neighborhood of Edgewater. The studio is bare bones and funky. There's no plumbing, but it's good sized, looks
title: ART/ARCHITECTURE; In Miami, a Hot Spot of Art, the Temperature's Rising

author: Jacques Godbout has published essays in Montreal and novels in Paris. He has made more than 30 films, including 4 features, all produced by the National Film Board of Canada. This article was translated from the French by Robert Gray, Kinograph.
body: WOULD the idea of holding a Quebec arts festival in New York have occurred to anyone 20 years ago? Probably not. We Quebecers were then still searching for an identity, unsure of our relationship to the Americas, embroiled in a literary and theatrical adventure in a French language that wavered among standardized forms, archaisms and original
title: THEATER: A Symbolic Nation Aspires to the International; A Symbolic Nation Aspires to the International

body: Voter News Service, an eight-year-old consortium that provides exit polling data for news organizations, will open corporate headquarters with 17,000 square feet of space next week in the small Brooklyn neighborhood called Dumbo (Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass), a spokeswoman for the consortium said yesterday. title: Metro Business Briefing | Polling Service To Move

body: It's official. Brooklyn and Queens have arrived, and they've got their own alternative weekly newspaper to prove it. On Thursday, more than a dozen neighborhoods received the debut issue of New York Metropolis, a free, 32-page publication that will be distributed almost exclusively in those boroughs. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; 2 Boroughs Arrive (Once Again) With a New Newspaper's Arrival

body: Eyebeam Atelier, a nonprofit arts and technology company in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, has been approved for rent abatement from the New York City Economic Development Corporation. Eyebeam is the first company to receive rent abatement as part of the E.D.C.'s commercial expansion program. Eyebeam Atelier will receive $11,275 in rent abatement
title: Metro Business Briefing | Company Receives Rent Break

body: ON the northwest edge of Bedford-Stuyvesant -- bordering the bodegas and housing projects of DeKalb Avenue, but only three blocks from the Italianate brownstones and Victorian mansions of Clinton Hill -- six former factories built on a street called Taaffe Place at the turn of the last century have been reincarnated as beautifully renovated
title: When New Homes Drive Out Old Jobs

body: Smack Mellon Studios 56 Water Street Dumbo, Brooklyn Through July 8 With its unpainted walls and creaky stairs, the 19th-century spice factory that serves as Smack Mellon's exhibition space is an ideal setting for this group show of work that is homemade, low-tech and proud. Mary Ziegler offers an airy kinetic sculpture fashioned from plastic dry
title: ART IN REVIEW; 'Popular Mechanics'

body: A FAMILIAR green image of a mermaid stands on Van Brunt Street in Red Hook, Brooklyn, near the corner of Coffey Street. ''Coming Soon,'' the sign says, ''Starbucks Coffey.'' Both a play on words and a joking reference to the neighborhood's nascent gentrification, the sign does not seem an accurate prediction -- at least not yet. With a long history
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Red Hook; Isolated Brooklyn Area Starts to Awaken

body: The streets, paved with nubby Belgian blocks, splay at awkward angles to the waterfront. The sidewalks run with rivulets of greasy blood, and prostitutes pick their way around discarded chunks of fat. title: After Blood and Guts, Seeking Landmark Glory; Many Residents Aim to Save Meatpackers Along With Neighborhood's Gritty Charm

body: Over the last 30 years, the tiny Brooklyn neighborhood of old industrial buildings and warehouses that is known as Dumbo has played host to all sorts of new tenants, from artists and offbeat performance companies to more recent arrivals like dot-com companies and well-heeled apartment seekers. title: Commercial Real Estate; Retailers Begin Popping Up in a Sliver of Brooklyn

body: THE slice of Brooklyn waterfront known as Dumbo (''down under the Manhattan Bridge overpass'') sits between the Manhattan and Brooklyn bridges, with 19th-century red-brick warehouses and streets paved with Belgian blocks. Today, the buildings are home to artists, furniture designers, upholsterers and metalworkers. ''The neighborhood is a real
title: PERSONAL SHOPPER; Dumbo Stands for Offbeat Furniture Heaven

body: WHEN entering StudioEIS in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, a visitor should be careful not to strike up a conversation with just anyone. It might prove embarrassing, or at least one-sided. StudioEIS, created and run by two brothers, Ivan and Elliot Schwartz, is known for producing remarkably lifelike plaster-and-plastic sculptures of figures
title: BACKSTAGE; Madame Tussaud These Two Are Not

body: Enter Michael Counts's hell at your own risk. The high-wind warning posted near the ticket table is for real. So is the one about ear-splitting sound. title: THEATER REVIEW; It's Strange and Unsettling, Adrift Amid Hellish Images

body: Hidden behind an unmarked door, a 2,000-square-foot loft space in a warehouse in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn contains hundreds of pieces of Anglo-Raj-style furniture. title: CURRENTS: WHO KNEW?; A Hidden Bombay in Brooklyn

body: Two high-end residential buildings, one under construction, the other in the pipeline, are accelerating the changes under way in Dumbo, the Brooklyn waterfront neighborhood whose name is an acronym for Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass. ''Rome was not built in a day but it's all happening now,'' said David C. Walentas, a developer who owns
title: POSTINGS: One a Rental, the Other Condo and Commercial; For Dumbo in Brooklyn, Two New Buildings

body: Starting a business in a relatively deserted area can be a gamble, no matter how up-and-coming the neighborhood is said to be. So when the owners of a Brooklyn Heights grocery, Peas and Pickles, decided to open a new store in the rapidly gentrifying area known as Dumbo, for Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass, they took nothing for granted.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK SUPERMARKETS; As Artists Move In, New Grocery Opens Up

body: NEW YORK BROOKLYN: TRUCE IN LOFT DISPUTE -- In a truce over disputed lofts in Dumbo, city officials met yesterday with the landlord of a building where 60 residents were removed last month. The officials' goal is to allow the residents to return to a factory building illegally converted to lofts at 247 Water Street. After the landlord, Joshua
title: METRO BRIEFING

body: Two weeks after promising a moratorium on forcing tenants out of illegally converted loft apartments, the city made an abortive attempt yesterday to evacuate about a dozen tenants from their lofts onto the freezing sidewalks of the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, officials and residents said. But the Buildings Department backed down amid chanting
title: City Move Against Lofts Is Aborted
